item.title: Restarting Audio in Ubuntu After Issues
item.dc:creator: Jason Meridth
item.description:
The following command restarted audio for me in Ubuntu after my microphone on my headphones stopped working.

pulseaudio -k && sudo alsa force-reload

Credit to: http://askubuntu.com/a/230893

item.title: I Finally Have Linux As My Native OS
item.dc:creator: Jason Meridth
item.description: I finally replaced OSX on my Mac with Ubuntu 14.04 LTS. Out of the box I've had no issues. Wireless, VPN, Terminal, Dropbox, Google Drive, LastPass, etc all work. I was spending more time in my Vagrant VMs with OSX anyway. Loved VirtualBox + Vagrant. Never had an issue. I just wasn't using any portion of OSX. It is nice to troubleshoot any issues and tweak my setup. I'm getting used to Unity and may drop it for Gnome3 and Gnome-Do. We'll see. Any new things I troubleshoot or find, I'll post on.

item.title: No More Password Prompts When Issuing Sudo Commands
item.dc:creator: Jason Meridth
item.description:
Edit the sudoers file:

sudo visudo

Add or edit the following line to be:

%sudo ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL

This will prevent password prompts for everyone in the sudo group (%sudo) when issuing all commands (NOPASSWD: ALL)

item.title: Renew DHCP Lease on Ubuntu VM After Moving Between Wireless Networks
item.dc:creator: Jason Meridth
item.description:
TL;DR

sudo dhclient -r [eth0] && sudo dhclient [eth0]

I add that command as an alias to my ~/.bashrc file

alias resetdhcp='sudo dhclient -r eth0 && sudo dhclient eth0'

then resourced it so I could use it in the bash session I was in

source ~/.bashrc

I constantly have my Ubuntu VM (VirtualBox) running on my Windows laptop and dock/undock it between work and home. Obviously those are two different wireless networks. Well, I was unable to find a dhcp renewal command that would work until today (look above).

This command releases and renews your DHCP IP Address.

I’m very happy about this.

dhclient man page

When run by itself, your instance will seek out a new ip lease.

item.title: Testing Mail From the Command Line on Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: Jason Meridth
item.description:
Install mailutils

sudo apt-get install mailutils

Send some test piped into the mail command

echo "testing" | mail -s Test user@emailhost.com

Check the email address listed above

item.title: Using Latest Version of Git on Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: Jason Meridth
item.description:
Whenever you do

sudo apt-get install git-core

on Ubuntu you will only get git version 1.7.5.x. I needed 1.7.6%2B.

To do this you have to run the following commands:

sudo apt-get install software-properties-common python-software-properties
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:git-core/ppa
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install git-core

This should give you git version 1.7.11 (as of today)
